Context:
Program Name: Recreation Management in Gerontology
Code: C152
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $3,932.00
International Tuition: $18,065.00
Centre: Health Sciences
School: Health & Wellness
Location: Waterfront Campus
Experiential Learning: Required field education in all four semesters
Program Description: The Recreation Management in Gerontology program will provide students with specialized knowledge in the field of aging and the ability to design and deliver meaningful therapeutic programs to enhance the quality of life of older adults. Graduates meet the requirements outlined in the "Fixing Long-Term Care Act" to work as a recreation lead or recreation team staff member.
Graduates can explore related programs such as Personal Support Worker (PSW) (C112), Hearing Instrument Specialist (S117), and Community Worker (C101).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Recreation Management in Gerontology Program C152 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
This Recreation Management in Gerontology program offers students the ability to work with people across different life stages, focusing on older adults. The science and theory of aging will be studied, including biological changes and related diseases such as Alzheimer's. Students will also learn about complementary and alternative therapies and end-of-life care perspectives. Hands-on training will take place at a 24,000+-square-foot Simulation Centre and with over 600 field placement partners. The latest industry software will be used for preparation in health-care settings. Students can expect to create and deliver innovative therapeutic recreational programs in various settings like long-term care facilities, retirement homes, hospitals, community-based service agencies, and adult day programs. Apply if energetic, organized, creative, and enjoy working with older adults for a rewarding career. Field education (work-integrated learning) is integrated throughout the program and offered in each semester, providing practical experience in health-care settings. Some clinical or work placement partners may require students to show proof of full COVID-19 vaccination.

Extracted Information:
- Focuses on older adults
- Science and theory of aging studied
- Includes biological changes and related diseases such as Alzheimer's
- Complementary and alternative therapies and end-of-life care perspectives taught
- Hands-on training provided at a Simulation Centre and with over 600 field placement partners
- Latest industry software used for health-care preparation
- Students create and deliver innovative therapeutic recreational programs in various settings (long-term care facilities, retirement homes, hospitals, community-based service agencies, adult day programs)
- Apply if energetic, organized, creative, and enjoy working with older adults
- Field education (work-integrated learning) offered throughout the program
- Some clinical or work placement partners require students to show proof of full COVID-19 vaccination.

Context: The Recreation Management in Gerontology program offers graduates the opportunity to apply for a reduced time frame (approximately 12–18 months) to complete a B.A. in gerontology at Laurentian University. Graduates with a B.A. in gerontology from Laurentian University can apply to complete the Recreation Management in Gerontology diploma in one year. The Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care (S417) postgraduate certificate program is offered for graduates with an interest in working in long-term care facilities. This two-semester program is delivered online and on-demand to accommodate working professionals, includes a clinical field placement component. Required courses for semester 1 include COMM 1081 – Interpersonal Communication Skills, GERT 1004 – Recreation I: Therapeutic Interventions, GERT 1038 – Pre-Placement Seminar, GERT 1018 – Field Practice I, GERT 1035 – Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Disorders, GERT 1033 – Introduction to Gerontology, and GERT 1010 – Aging in Place. For more information about Laurentian University applications, contact admissions@laurentian.ca. For Recreation Management in Gerontology diploma inquiries, email Program Co-ordinator and Professor Pamela Gauci at pamela.gauci@georgebrown.ca.

Context:
The text provides a list of courses and their codes for Semesters 2 to 4 in a Gerontology program at the college. The courses include:

Semester 2:
- GERT 1025: Integrated Seminar I
- COMM 1000: Introduction to College Communication (may be required based on placement test results)
- GERT 1027: Integrated Seminar II
- GERT 1012: Assessment Skills and Inter-RAI Methodology
- GERT 1036: Management I: Foundation Skills
- INTRODUCTION TO BIOLOGY OF AGING (GERT 1015 not listed in the text but mentioned in Semester 2's description)

Semester 3:
- GERT 2004: Management II: Professional Development
- GERT 2009: Field Practice III
- GERT 2016: Integrated Seminar III
- GERT 2028: Recreation III: Alternative Therapeutic Programming
- GERT 2031: Ethical and Professional Leadership
- SWRK 2001: Group Processes
- Two General Education Electives (GNED)

Semester 4:
- GERT 2006: Activation Industry Resources
- GERT 2023: Governance of Services for Older Adults
- GERT 1043: Living with Dying
- GERT 2011: Field Practice IV
- GERT 1014: Psychogeriatrics
- GERT 2018: Integrated Seminar IV
- SWRK 2000: Management III: Human Resources
- One General Education Elective (GNED)

The graduate of the program will be able to function effectively as an interprofessional team member, accurately and comprehensively assess older adults, develop, coordinate, deliver and evaluate services/programs, and apply appropriate health and safety protocols.

Certain students may need to take COMM 1000: Introduction to College Communication before progressing to COMM 2000. Students should visit the Assessment Centre webpage for more information.

Context:
The text provides information about the requirements and expectations for students in the Activation Gerontology program at George Brown College. Here is the extracted information:

1. The program focuses on applying research and theory to practice, ensuring health and safety protocols, communicating effectively, identifying and using resources, operating programs in compliance with policies, establishing ethical standards, promoting accessibility, managing resources, and tuition fees.
2. Tuition fees for the first two semesters of the program starting in Fall 2023 for domestic students is $3,932.00, and for international students it is $18,065.00. The text mentions that these amounts are subject to change.
3. The program is approved for OSAP (Ontario Student Assistance Program) funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.
4. Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent and a grade 12 English (C) or (U) with a minimum grade of 60 per cent to be considered for admission.
5. The text includes a disclaimer that the information on the website is subject to change without notice.

Context:
* Applicants for grade 12 English with a minimum grade of 60 percent are recommended to attend an information session.
* Admissions decisions are based on academic credit, but applicants are encouraged to accumulate at least 40 volunteer hours working with older adults prior to applying.
* Mature students (19 years old or above without OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to get English credits needed.
* Meeting minimum requirements does not guarantee admission to a program, and applicants may need higher grades than stated.
* College or university credits may qualify students for course exemptions; check the Transfer Guide for more information.
* International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Students must meet and complete mandatory Pre-placement requirements upon acceptance into the program, which takes up to 8-10 weeks.
* Students need to provide medical records (TB Skin Test, COVID-19 and flu shot) and Vulnerable Sector Check renewed annually by the program's specific deadline on ParaMed Placement Pass website.
* Unvaccinated students against COVID-19 may not be able to complete field placements in the regularly scheduled time frame.
* Students who don't comply with health policy and non-academic requirements or fail to submit documentation by deadlines will be excluded from clinical practicum, which could jeopardize academic standing and successful completion of the program.
* All costs related to overall health requirements are students' responsibility.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Recreation Management in Gerontology Program C152 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
Students in this program are required to have a Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed every year before entering into field or clinical placement. The Vulnerable Sector Check process typically takes two to three months but can take four to eight months. Students are responsible for ensuring that the police record check covers appropriateness for "individuals being employed and/or volunteering who will be working with vulnerable person(s)." Students are required to keep the original copy of their Vulnerable Sector Check. If a student is unable to provide a "clear" vulnerable sector check, they may not be able to start their field or clinical placement and may jeopardize their progress in the program. Fees for the vulnerable sector check vary and must be paid by the student.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact the George Brown School of Health and Wellness at 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. or email hwprograms@georgebrown.ca for more information about the program. For general information about George Brown College, contact the Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002. International students can also contact one of George Brown's international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry.

Students are required to have a Vulnerable Sector Check completed and renewed every year for clinical placements, and may be unable to complete the program if they cannot provide a clear check. The fees for the vulnerable sector check vary. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Contact information is provided for the George Brown School of Health and Wellness, as well as the college's Contact Centre and international recruitment representatives.
